data.title: A Touch of Ginger
data.text:
Hey all,

I’M BACK!! Sorry for the very long, and unexpected hiatus, but I have come back and I am ready to do pump some reviews, fun little articles, and anything pop culture.

What better way than to give my predictions for the Academy Awards that will honor the best films of 2015. 2015 was a pretty good year for film, and I really like the fact that there is no clear winner in many categories this season. It could go either way on Sunday night. With no further ado, here are the Ginger’s predictions for 88th Academy Awards.

(Side Note: Due to knowing very little information, the following categories of Best Documentary Short Subject, Best Live Action Short Film, and Best Animated Short Film will not be covered in this prediction. Also, like last year, I will be making symbols to say who will, should, and could be the recipients of these awards. The text in bold indicated who I think will win, the nominee with an asterisks (*) indicates who I think should win, and the nominee with a plus sing (+) indicates who I think could win, based on other award trends or complete surprise. )

THE TECHINICAL CATEGORIES

BEST SOUND EDITING

Mad Max: Fury Road *

The Martian

The Revenant +

Sicario

Star Wars: The Force Awakens *

BEST SOUND MIXING

Bridge of Spies

Mad Max: Fury Road +

The Martian

The Revenant

Star Wars: The Force Awakens *

These categories are ones that I confuse one from the other, so I am going to do them together, which also saves time. When it comes to the Sound Editing category I feel like this is one for Mad Max: Fury Road to lose, however I would not be upset if Star Wars: The Force Awakens would receive the award, as I feel are both deserving. Do not count out The Revenant though. The sound editing was very good in that film, and it could be one of the many awards I am sure it will receive that night. In terms of Sound Mixing, I really feel Star Wars: The Force Awakens did a wonderful job with its mixing and design. There were sounds that I was surprised to be hearing certain scenes that made my viewing the film even more enjoyable. Although, Mad Max: Fury Road could still win the award. Again, these categories are a tough call.

BEST VISUAL EFFECTS

Ex Machina *

Mad Max: Fury Road

The Martian

The Revenant +

Star Wars: The Force Awakens *

This category is definitely something that is Star Wars’ to lose. The visual effects in Star Wars: The Force Awakens were so cool. One of the effects in the film that I enjoyed was the character of Maz Kanata. She was just executed beautifully in this film. Though, I would not count out Ex Machina and The Revenant. Like Star Wars: The Force Awakens, I feel Ex Machina should receive this award. The look of Alicia Vikander in the film is so interesting, and I loved how “non-computery” (yes, I made up a word) her character looked in this film. The Revenant could win the award for one reason, the bear attack. That’s all I need to say.

BEST FILM EDITING

The Big Short

Mad Max: Fury Road +

The Revenant *

Spotlight

Star Wars: The Force Awakens

When it comes to the Best Film Editing of 2015, the only film that came to my mind is The Revenant. There were scenes that were crafted and cut beautifully, especially the ones that had seemed like one long shot throughout the scene. Plus, this would be a way to honor Stephen Mirrione, who was the film editor for this film and last year’s Best Picture winner Birdman (and he should have been nominated last year because the film editing in Birdman was incredible). Although, Mad Max: Fury Road could still win the award because there were sequences that were cut and edited quite brilliantly in that film.

BEST CINEMATOGRAPHY

Carol

The Hateful Eight

Mad Max: Fury Road

The Revenant *

Sicario +

Just like Film Editing, I feel this is a definite win for The Revenant. There are so many scenes that are shot beautifully in this film, and the imagery in this film just makes your jaw drop and sometimes see beauty in this pretty gruesome film. Also, the use of natural light really was something I loved in this movie, especially one scene at night with men using torches for light. The night scenes literally are authentic and not shot in the day then “blue toned”. However, Sicario’s cinematography was really cool, especially the scene that is entirely in night vision, and it could win the award on Sunday night.

THE DESIGN CATEGORIES

BEST MAKE UP AND HAIRSTYLING

The 100-Year Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared

Mad Max: Fury Road *+

The Revenant

This category is a definite win for Mad Max: Fury Road. The design of the make-up is executed very well on film. There are some actors that do not look recognizable in this film (i.e. Nicholas Hoult and Charlize Theron), and it really does a great job of painting this dystopian world that Max and Furiosa live in.

BEST COSTUME DESIGN

Carol

Cinderella *

The Danish Girl *+

Mad Max: Fury Road

The Revenant

I was very pleased to see Cinderella get the nomination for Costume Design because I felt that Sandy Powell’s designs were beautiful and really one the stars of the film. The iconic dress that Ella wears to the ball was STUNNING, as well as Helena Bonham Carter’s and Cate Blanchett’s. Those three designs alone should give the film the award because those dresses are beautiful. However, I also loved the costume designs in The Danish Girl. Eddie Redmayne’s costumes were so elegant and well tailored to his body, that I felt they really did a great job with helping him act as Lili Elbe. Also, Alicia Vikander’s costumes were just as exquisite. So, I feel it’s between Cinderella and The Danish Girl, and although I want Cinderella to win, I would not be upset if the latter receive this award.

BEST PRODUCTION DESIGN

Bridge of Spies +

The Danish Girl *

Mad Max: Fury Road

The Martian

The Revenant

I feel like this is one of the definite awards that The Danish Girl will receive tomorrow night. The design of the set pieces in the film are beautiful, elegant, and at some points simplistic. However, Bridge of Spies sets were quite classic and really did a create job at painting a time period in history that was not so long ago.

THE FEATURE FILM CATEGORIES

BEST DOCUMENTARY FEATURE FILM

Amy *

Cartel Land

The Look of Silence

What Happened, Miss Simone? +

Winter on Fire: Ukraine’s Fight for Freedom

There is no question that the recipient of the Best Documentary Feature award will by Amy on Sunday night. This documentary was not only well crafted, but it really gives us light into the tragic life of this amazing musician and vocalist that was gone too soon. Although, What Happened, Miss Simone? is another great music documentary film that could win this award. But, I still feel Amy will be the recipient.

BEST FOREIGN LANGUAGE FILM

Embrace of the Serpent (Country: Colombia; Language: Spanish)

Mustang (Country: France; Language: Turkish)

Son of Saul (Country: Hungary; Language: Hungarian) *+

Theeb (Country: Jordan; Language: Arabic)

A War (Country: Denmark; Language: Danish)

Son of Saul has been getting a great deal of press for some time, and although I have not seen all of the films in this category, I genuinely feel this will be the recipient for Best Foreign Language Film. This is based on the reviews I’ve read, some clippings I’ve seen, and the fact it won the Golden Globe Award for Best Foreign Language Film.

BEST ANIMATED FEATURE FILM

Anomalisa

Boy & The World

Inside Out *+

Shaun the Sheep Movie

When Marnie Was There

There is no question that Inside Out will win the Best Animated Feature Film category. Disney/Pixar did not only make a great comeback with this film, but they really released a film that touched so many people. The concept was wonderful and well crafted, and there are very few animated films that talk about feelings and the emotions we process. I really feel it was a novel way to present this as a family film, and it really is just a solid, great film.

THE MUSIC AND WRITING CATEGORIES

BEST ORIGINAL SONG

Fifty Shades of Grey – “Earned It”

The Hunting Ground – “Till It Happens to You” *

Racing Extinction – “Manta Ray”

Spectre – “Writing’s on the Wall” *+

Youth – “Simple Song #3”

This award was tough to pick a recipient. All the songs are great, but there are two that really stand out. Overall, because of the message and the fact that it is a killer song, I feel “’Till It Happens to You” for The Hunting Ground (written by Lady Gaga and Diane Warren) will, and should, receive the award. Although, I also love the song “Writing’s on the Wall” from Spectre (written by Sam Smith and Jimmy Napes) and feel it should, and could, win the award. Either one of them, I would be happy with in the end.

BEST ORIGINAL SCORE

Bridge of Spies – Thomas Newman

Carol – Carter Burwell

The Hateful Eight – Ennio Morricone *

Sicario – Johann Johannsson

Star Wars: The Force Awakens – John Williams +

I really enjoyed the score from The Hateful Eight, and I feel it will receive the award for Best Orignal Score. It also really does a great job at painting this spaghetti western/sort of good, bad and ugly world that Quentin Tarrantino in the film. Although I still loved John William’s score in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. There were new themes introduced that were just beautiful, and it could win the award tomorrow night.

BEST ORIGINAL SCREENPLAY

Bridge of Spies – Matt Charman, Joel Coen and Ethan Coen

Ex Machina – Alex Garland +

Inside Out – Pete Docter, Meg LeFauve, Josh Cooley and Ronnie del Carmen

Spotlight – Tom McCarthy and Josh Singer *

Straight Outta Compton – Jonathan Herman, Andrea Berloff, S. Leigh Savidge and Alan Wenkus *

This is a really good group of nominees this year. The two film’s screenplays that really stand out to me were Spotlight and Straight Outta Compton. Overall, I feel Spotlight will win, but both are deserving of this award. Their screenplays were so well written, and there were some scenes that were so powerful that not only could they have been executed brilliantly with amazing actors on screen, but with incredible writing. Also, I would not count out Ex Machina. The story line is very well written, and there are some scenes that really make this science fiction thriller quite exciting.

BEST ADAPTED SCREENPLAY

The Big Short – Adam McKay and Charles Randolph

Brooklyn – Nick Harnby

Carol – Phyllis Nagy

The Martian – Drew Goddard *

Room – Emma Donoghue *+

This category is a definite win for The Martian. The script, adapted from Andy Weir’s novel, was well adapted, nerdy, witty, and dramatic at times. It really was a well written film, and if it does not win the Academy Award for Best Picture, this will definitely be the award to honor this movie. Although, I also loved how well Room was adapted to the screen by the novel’s same author, Emma Donoghue. There were some scenes that I remember from reading the book, that I was just floored by seeing come to life on screen, especially scenes involving Jack experiencing the world for the first time. Overall, both scripts are deserving and I would not be upset if either one of them one.

THE ACTING CATEGORIES

BEST SUPPORTING ACTRESS

Jennifer Jason Leigh – The Hateful Eight; Role – Daisy Domergue

Rooney Mara – Carol; Role – Therese Belivet

Rachel McAdams – Spotlight; Role – Sacha Pfeiffer

Alicia Vikander – The Danish Girl; Role – Gerda Wegener *

Kate Winslet – Steve Jobs; Role – Joanna Hoffman +

I honestly feel this is Alicia Vikander’s award to win. Her performance in The Danish Girl was so beautiful, and so heart breaking at times, that she just lit up on the screen as Gerda Wegener. Also, this would be a way to honor her work this year in other films, such as Ex Machina (which she was incredible in) and Burnt. However, I really did like Kate Winslet’s performance as Joanna Hoffman in Steve Jobs. It was a very solid performance, and she won the Golden Globe. However, I still feel it will be Alicia.

BEST SUPPORTING ACTOR

Christian Bale – The Big Short; Role – Michael Burry

Tom Hardy – The Revenant; Role – John Fitzgerald +

Mark Ruffalo – Spotlight; Role – Michael Rezendes *

Mark Rylance – Bridge of Spies; Role – Rudolf Abel

Sylvester Stallone – Creed; Role – Rocky Balboa

I strongly feel that Sylvester Stallone will finally win an Oscar for a Rocky film. And from what I’ve heard, because Creed is one the very few films I did not see this awards season, he does give a great performance. However, I also feel that the award should go to Mark Ruffalo for his performance as Michael Rezendes in Spotlight. It was really powerful and moving, and it really shows off Ruffalo’s incredible acting chops. But, I would not count out Tom Hardy as the villainous John Fitzgerald in The Revenant. He truly is a great actor who disappears in his roles, and he gave a really great haunting performance in this film. So overall, I feel Sylvestor Stallone will go home with an Oscar, but I still think it should be Mark Ruffalo, and could be Tom Hardy.

BEST LEADING ACTRESS

Cate Blanchett – Carol; Role – Carol Aird

Brie Larson – Room; Role – Joy “Ma” Newsome *

Jennifer Lawrence – Joy; Role – Joy Mangano

Charlotte Rampling – 45 Years; Role – Kate Mercer

Saorise Ronan – Brooklyn; Role – Eilis Lacey *+

Like Alicia Vikander in the Supporting Actress category, I strongly feel this is Brie Larson’s definite win in the Best Leading Actress category. Larson’s performance as Joy “Ma” Newsome in Room was powerful, sometimes tragic, but also very strong as a mother thinking about nothing but for her and her son to survive. She took us there, and really gives an incredible performance. Also, her chemistry on screen with Jacob Tremblay is incredible and really makes the film. However, I also feel that Saorise Ronan gave an incredible performance this year as Eilis Lacey in Brooklyn. She could win the award, but I still strongly feel it is Brie Larson who will receive the gold statue tomorrow night.

BEST LEADING ACTOR

Bryan Cranston – Trumbo; Role – DaltonT rumbo

Matt Damon – The Martian; Role – Mark Watney +

Leonardo DiCaprio – The Revenant; Role – Hugh Glass *

Michael Fassbender – Steve Jobs; Role – Steve Jobs

Eddie Redmayne – The Danish Girl; Role – Lili Elbe/Einar Wegener

FINALLY, IT IS LEO’S YEAR!!! Leonardo DiCaprio is finally going to win an Academy Award for his performance as Hugh Glass in The Revenant. He literally is put through the ringer in the film, and although he says very little dialogue in this film, he says so much with his face and motions in this film. He literally gives a tour de force performance and deserves an Oscar. However, I would not cut out Matt Damon. Matt Damon gave a enjoyable performance as Mark Watney in The Martian. But overall, still Leo’s night.

BEST DIRECTOR

Adam McKay – The Big Short

George Miller – Mad Max: Fury Road

Alejandro G. Iñárritu – The Revenant

Lenny Abrahamson – Room +

Tom McCarthy – Spotlight *

I feel like this is going to be a back to back win for Alejandro G. Iñárritu. What he did with The Revenant was very interesting, and I feel he did a great job at being the captain of this ship and creating this incredible film about revenge and survival. However, I also feel the award should go to Tom McCarthy. He did an exquisite job with this very powerful film about a very historical time in journalism. But Lenny Abrahamson could win the award for Room. Not only did he have the incredible challenge of directing this heavy film, but to also direct actors in a small space and a child. Overall three directors are deserving, and I feel it will go to Iñárritu even though it should go to McCarthy, and do not count out Abrahamson.

BEST PICTURE

The Big Short

Bridge of Spies

Brooklyn

Mad Max: Fury Road

The Martian

The Revenant *+

Room

Spotlight *

If you asked me when the nominations first came out, I would have said The Revenant would win Best Picture. I still feel The Revenant should win Best Picture because it is a great well-crafted film. However, I strongly feel that Spotlight should win and it will win for Best Picture. It tells a powerful story, has a great director and screenplay, and a cast that gives a stellar performance. The picture as a whole is incredible. So to clarify my answer, I feel Spotlight will, and should, be selected for Best Picture, however I also think The Revenant should, and could, win the award for Best Picture.

Well there are my predictions for the 88th Academy Awards for the films of 2015. I hope you enjoy watching the awards ceremony on ABC tomorrow night starting at 8 pm, as I will. I also look forward to some more blog posts to come. If you feel inclined to watch any films nominated before tomorrow night, you can stream them on Amazon and iTunes, and rent most of them through Redbox.

Until next time,

Your Favorite Ginger

Hello all!!! I’m back!!

So, sorry about the 3 month hiatus, but things got a little hectic. But, I’m back and now a more perfect time than ever! It’s the the post summer film season, which means it’s Oscar season, which besides Christmas and the Tony’s is the most wonderful time of the year.

But, I’m not knocking down this past summer’s film season because there were some great films this year, some better than last summer. I really enjoyed them! So to commemorate a very well done summer film season, I am giving the Ginger’s top picks from the summer 2015 film season. I’ve narrowed it down to 9 films out of the the many that I saw! I do apologize in advance for the lovers of Ant-Man and Trainwreck because I was not able to make it to the theater to see them. And I do apologize for the one fan of The Fantastic Four reboot….I didn’t bother with that P.O.S. Sorry I’m not sorry!

FAIR WARNING: In case anyone is wondering why I give all the information at every film in the countdown, it’s because I am giving you the option to say yes and no to this film. If there is a star you don’t really like in it, then don’t watch it. If you were feeling half and half about a film, and see the time length and feel you’re not going to get that time back….then don’t watch it!

So here we go!!!

9. Ricki and the Flash

Release Date: August 14, 2015

Rating: PG-13 for thematic material, brief drug content, sexuality and language.

Running Time: 1 hr. 41 mins.

Director: Jonathan Demme

Screenwriter: Diablo Cody

Cast: Meryl Streep, Kevin Kline, Mamie Gummer, Audra McDonald, Sebastian Stan, Nick Westrate, Rick Springfield, Ben Platt

Okay, put away your judging face. This film was one of those gems that I really enjoyed this year. Yes the script was predictable, but the film had it’s moments. There was a great performance given by Meryl Streep, who could win an Oscar reciting her ABCs in a potato sack. Kevin Kline was fantastic and it was so nice to see them together in a film that was a comedy, and not a hard drama like Sophie’s Choice. Audra McDonald took a pretty small, supporting role, gave it the Audra McDonald touch, and made it a force of nature. Finally, Mamie Gummer, who was a scene stealer in this film, taught us all that she was an apple that did not fall far from the tree with her amazing talent. Also, this film did it’s job and made us forget our troubles for over 90 minutes, and make it an enjoyable night in the theatre. This is a film that is very much worth a view.

8. Magic Mike XXL

Release Date: July 1, 2015

Rating: R for strong sexual content, pervasive language, some nudity (DUH) and some drug use

Running Time: 1 hr. 55 mins.

Director: Gregory Jacobs

Screenwriter: Reid Carolin

Cast: Channing Tatum, Matt Bomer, Joe Manganiello, Kevin Nash, Adam Rodriguez, Gabriel Iglesias, Amber Heard, Donald Glover, Andie MacDowell, Elizabeth Banks, Jada Pinkett Smith

Okay, I think every lady and gay man will agree with me when I say this…I really disliked Magic Mike. I felt the first film was too much Mike and not enough magic. However, Magic Mike XXL was the total opposite. It was so funny, energetic and kept me interested in so many of these characters. I really feel this is how the first film should have been all along. And the real reason to see this film, besides the iconic scene with Joe Mangnaiello in a gas station, is for the last 15-20 minutes. I don’t want to say anymore about that without giving too much of that away. But, just to advise people who did not like the first film, watch the second film. It’s funnier, sexier, and has a great cast that pleases all sexes.

7. Mad Max: Fury Road

Release Date: May 15, 2015

Rating: R for intense sequences of violence and disturbing images

Running Time: 2 hours

Director: George Miller

Screenwriter: George Miller, Brendan McCarthy, Nico Lathouris

Cast: Tom Hardy, Charlize Theron, Nicholas Hoult, Hugh Keays-Byrne, Rosie Huntington-Whitely, Riley Keough, Zoë Kravitz, Abbey Lee, Courtney Eaton

Here’s the thing about Mad Max, I’m not a big fan of the series in general. However, this film was very good. It was not the best film for the summer for me, but it was definitely one of the most entertaining films for me. Charlize Theron was a BAMF, as always, and Tom Hardy was a very likable Max. Nicholas Hoult was crazy, and Hugh Keays-Byrne…..yeah he was weird. Overall, despite my personal feelings about the film series and about this film personally, it was an action packed film that kept me entertained, and it did live up to the hype a bit. Plus, there was this awesome guitar guy for the villain’s theme music. For all you folks that like lots of action, explosions and stunts, this is the film for you.

6. Spy

Release Date: June 5, 2015

Rating: R for language, violence and some sexual content

Running Time: 2 hours (Unrated Extended Edition – 2 hrs. 10 mins.)

Director and Screenwriter: Paul Feig

Cast: Melissa McCarthy, Jason Statham, Rose Byrne, Miranda Hart, Bobby Cannavale, Allison Janney, Jude Law

I came into this film with very, very low expectations, and came out loving this quite hysterical film. At first I did not want to watch this film because I find Melissa McCarthy to be sometimes obnoxious, however her role in this movie was the complete opposite. She was literally a caterpillar that turned into a comedic butterfly. Her one liners were gut busters and her comedic timing was perfect in this film. Not to mention her scene partner, Rose Byrne, held her own, and it was nice to see them together in a film since Bridesmaids. Another great scene stealer in this film was Miranda Hart. She was that best girl friend you want to have all the time, and nailed the awkward humor. Finally, Jude Law, Bobby Cannavale, and Jason Stratham were wonderful in their roles. For all those Johnny English and James Bond fans, this is definitely a film for you.

5. Avengers: Age of Ultron

Release Date: May 1, 2015

Rating: PG-13 for intense sequences of sci-fi action, violence and destruction, and some suggestive comments

Running Time: 2 hrs. 21 mins.

Director and Screenwriter: Joss Whedon

Cast: Robert Downey, Jr., Chris Evans, Chris Hemsworth, Mark Ruffalo, Scarlett Johansson, Jeremy Renner, Don Cheadle, Aaron Taylor-Johnson, Elizabeth Olsen, Paul Bettany, Cobie Smulders, Anthony Mackie, Hayley Atwell, Idris Elba, Stellan Skarsgard, James Spader, Samuel L. Jackson

This was definitely one of the films I was very excited about for this summer.To say this film was epic would be an understatement. It met my expectations, and maybe a little bit more. Not only was Joss Whedon’s script smart, but he did a wonderful job at meeting the bar that the first film set, and maybe a little farther. Also, this film had so much eye candy, you can’t even stand it. Finally, if you’re a huge marvel fan like I am, you will not be disappointed in this film, and really like what they have done with the Ultron character, as well as the Elizabeth Olsen and Aaron Taylor-Johnson introduced in this film.

4. Straight Outta Compton

Release Date: August 14, 2015

Rating: R for language, strong sexuality/nudity, violence and drug use

Running Time: 2 hrs. 27 mins.

Director: F. Gary Gray

Screenwriter: Jonathan Herman and Andrea Berloff

Cast: O’Shea Jackson, Jr., Corey Hawkins, Jason Mitchell, Paul Giamatti, Aldis Hodge, Neil Brown, Jr.

I am going out on a limb here and say that this was the biggest surprise of the summer. The actor’s performances were incredible, the script was very well written, and is definitely with the likes of Ray and Walk the Line in terms of music biopic films. It also, like our film selected for the number one slot, gave you this nostalgia of the 90s. I’m not gonna lie, I got excited when “Fuck da Police” started playing in the film, and when I heard the phrase “Bye Felicia”. Finally, I would just like to point out how scary, crazy, on point each actor’s resemblance were to their real life counterparts in N.W.A. (Spoiler alert: one of them is actually Ice Cube’s son). This is one of those films you should not pass up, and when it becomes available to rent or view, do not hesitate because it is a solid, excellent film.

3. Pitch Perfect 2

Release Date: May 15, 2015

Rating: PG-13 for innuendo and language

Running Time: 1 hr. 55 mins.

Director: Elizabeth Banks

Screenwriter: Kay Cannon

Cast: Anna Kendrick, Rebel Wilson, Hailee Steinfeld, Brittany Snow, Skylar Astin, Adam DeVine, Ben Platt, Anna Camp, Elizabeth Banks, John Michael Higgins, Ester Dean, Hana Mae Lee, Alexis Knapp, Chrissie Fit, Kelley Jakle, Shelley Regner, Katey Sagal, Birgitte Hjort Sørensen, Flula Borg, David Cross, Keegan-Michael Key

Just like Avengers: Age of Ultron, I was very excited about Pitch Perfect 2. This film was not only great but it surpassed the bar met by the first film, which is very hard. The music used in the film was fun, the arrangements were genius (especially The Riff-Off in this film), and the comedy in this film was on point. I loved that there were some new characters introduced that really held their own, and that Rebel and Anna were just as hysterical as always. Finally, Elizabeth Bank’s direction in this film was very well done, and she did a spectacular job (HEY LADIES!!!). If you have not seen this film yet, get out of the rock you are living under, and watch this hilarious movie.

2. Inside Out

Release Date: June 19, 2015

Rating: PG for mild thematic elements and some action

Running Time: 1 hr. 34 mins.

Director: Pete Docter

Screenwriter: Pete Docter, Meg LeFauve, Josh Cooley

Cast: Amy Poehler, Phyllis Smith, Bill Hader, Lewis Black, Mindy Kaling, Richard Kind, Kaitlyn Dias, Diane Lane, Kyle MacLachlan

To say that I felt all the feels in this film would be an understatement. This film was not only fun to watch, and visually beautiful, but the film was emotionally beautiful. You felt anger, sadness, joy, disgust and fear, all at different moments in this movie. Disney/Pixar really out did themselves in this movie, and succeeded going out on a limb with the premise of this film. Plus, everyone one in this film was brilliantly cast in the voicing of the characters, especially Amy Poehler, as Joy, Phyllis Smith, as Sadness, and Mindy Kaling, as Disgust. This not only a great film for the kids, but for the adults and the the inner child in us. Definitely a great film for family movie night.

1. Jurassic World

Release Date: June 10, 2015

Rating: PG-13 for intense sequences of sci-fi violence and peril

Running Time: 2 hrs. 4 mins.

Director: Colin Trevorrow

Screenwriter: Rick Jaffa, Amanda Silver, Derek Connolly, Colin Trevorrow

Cast: Chris Pratt, Bryce Dallas Howard, Vincent D’Onofrio, Ty Simpkins, Nick Robinson, Omar Sy, B.D. Wong, Irrfan Khan

I was so excited for this film, and like Straight Outta Compton, it brought back nostalgia to the 90s and the first time I saw Jurassic Park. The film was entertaining, met the formula of every Jurassic film, and had a stellar cast. Chris Pratt was great in this film and, like in Guardians of the Galaxy, showed how truly sexy he can be. Bryce Dallas-Howard was wonderful as always, and impressive when she running in them heels (SHE BETTAH!!). Finally, the dinosaurs were awesome and there were moments in the film that were extremely action packed, jaw dropping, and will make you jump up and down with excitement in your seat. Definitely a great film to add to this wonderful, awesome series.

Well, there you have it, the Ginger’s top films of the summer of 2015. If you have any favorite films this summer, please feel free to state it in the comment section below. I am glad to be back and I am excited to begin reviewing more films, and giving you all these great options for you to watch on any kind of day, or for any kind of occasion.

See you all the next time, folks!

Yours truly,

Your Favorite Ginger

“Good morning, good morning, it’s great to stay up late! Good morning, good morning to you!”

Hey all!

So you’re probably wondering where I’ve been…all 33 of you. Well, here’s what’s been happening. I GRADUATED! I now have my Master’s of Music in Vocal Performance. I’m master James now! So, that’s the main reason why I really haven’t posted anything in the past two months. I was in the the seventh inning stretch, plus there wasn’t anything to review in April, or I didn’t think of something creatively. HOWEVER! Now May has ended, June is bustin’ out all over (Sorry I’m not sorry for these musical theatre references), and I have some items to blog about.

It’s perfect that I come back from my unexpected hiatus with my favorite time of year, next to the holidays and Oscar season. IT’S THE TONY AWARDS! For those of you do not know much about these awards, or what the night is about in general, Tony Award night is a time where we recognize excellence in theatre with plays and musicals (both original and revival) that have opened from June-May of the following year (which is how long a season lasts on the Broadway calendar). I did a prediction of last year’s Tony Awards for the 2013-2014 theatre season, and that was my first prediction column on this blog.

I love the Tony Awards because not only does it recognize talent outside of the Grammys and the Academy Awards, but it really opens so many people across America to Broadway. It showcases also the plays that opened during the season, there are musical performances from nominated and not nominated musicals…it’s literally a huge show. I can say now that it’s been a while, but my first Tony Awards broadcast I ever watched was in 2003. I was finishing 6th grade, and it was the year Hairspray won Best Musical, Bernadette Peters was nominated for Gypsy and gave a stellar performance of “Rose’s Turn”, and Movin’ Out was the hottest jukebox musical on Broadway next to Mamma Mia!. It was the first time I ever heard of Broadway, what they were, what musicals besides the ones by Disney were opening or running, and seeing people that have made careers and been recognized for their work. Since then, that little 6th grader was inspired to do so many musicals, plays and eventually operas. So, basically we can thank my love of performing to the Tony Awards.

So, with no further ado, and quickly since I spent way too much time on these opening paragraphs, here are the Ginger’s predictions for the 69th Annual Tony Awards. (Sidenote: For the first time ever, I am doing both plays and musicals because I finally took time to look into some of the plays that opened this year, and for once did not care about the musicals.) Like the previous predictions here are what each symbol means: if the nominee is in bold text that stands for my pick/what I think will win, if the nominee has an astrix next to it (*) that stands for what I think should win, and if the nominee has a plus sign next to it (+) that stands for what I think could win.

TECHNICAL,CHOREOGRAPHY AND DIRECTING CATEGORIES

BEST LIGHTING DESIGN OF A PLAY

Airline Highway

The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time*

Skylight

Wolf Hall: Parts One & Two +

Like most of the play categories of the evening, this is a definite deadlock for The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time. From everything I’ve seen, the lighting looks beautiful and the lighting really pops out. It also does this beautiful job of bringing us into Christopher’s world, and has an amazing blend of projections with bright lights on that stage. Although, Wolf Hall‘s lighting is very dramatic and just as amazing as Curious Incident, and we probably shouldn’t count that show out.

BEST LIGHTING DESIGN OF A MUSICAL

An American in Paris

Fun Home*

Rodgers and Hammerstein’s The King and I +

The Visit

I really feel like that technically this is one of the awards Fun Home will win tomorrow evening. The fact that they lit this music so brilliantly in the round after being in a proscenium setting, is something that I commend the creative team. I really feel that this show deserves this award. However, another show that we should count out is the revival of The King and I. That production’s lighting is one of the many reasons why it is so exquisite and breathtaking, so we should not count the show out of that category.

BEST COSTUME DESIGN OF A PLAY

Airline Highway

The Audience +

Wolf Hall: Parts One & Two*

You Can’t Take It With You

I feel like there is no competition with this award. Wolf Hall’s costumes are beautifully designed, constructed and executed. Plus, who does not love a design of the Tudor period? However, we should not count out the costume design for The Audience. Helen Mirren’s costumes from the iconic tweed skirt suit to the coronation dress are beautiful.

BEST COSTUME DESIGN OF A MUSICAL

An American in Paris

Rodgers and Hammerstein’s The King and I*

On the Twentieth Century

Something Rotten! +

I strongly believe that this award is a dead lock for The King and I. I mean look at the dress on Kelli O’Hara. It’s seriously the most gorgeous ball gowns I’ve seen on Broadway, and the interview with Catherine Zuber still boggles my mind when she talks about the period undergarments Kelli is wearing in order to move in that dress. Also the pallets for the King, his wives and the children are exquisite, and the design of their costumes are just gorgeous and look beautiful on every single actor. I strongly believe Catherine Zuber is one of those designers who can really construct a costume just as brilliantly as William Ivey-Long. However, with my luck, it could go in the opposite direction and go to Something Rotten!, which have some incredible Elizabethan pieces on that stage.

BEST SCENIC DESIGN OF A PLAY

The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time*

Skylight

Wolf Hall: Parts One & Two

You Can’t Take It With You +

This set design is ingenious. It not only sets the world of Christopher very well, but has this amazing concept of being a huge playground for the actors, and a beautiful way of fluidly making stairs, and using compartments for props. How it is constructed still boggles me to this day. However, I do feel the revival of You Can’t Take It With You could also win because it truly is a beautiful, well constructed and detailed Broadway set.

BEST SCENIC DESIGN OF A MUSICAL

An American in Paris

Fun Home*

Rodgers and Hammerstein’s The King and I

On the Twentieth Century +

Like costume design, I feel this might be a lock for The King and I. I do not know what it is about Lincoln Center, but when they put on a production, not only is is simplistic, but has epic tones that are jaw dropping. However, I firmly believe Fun Home is equally as deserving because they completely changed their entire look and concept for their set, and it was beautifully executed in my opinion. I would not be upset if this show won the category. However, we should not count out On the Twentieth Century. The fact that they are putting a train on that small stage is incredible and still boggles my mind.

BEST CHOREOGRAPHY

Joshua Bergasse – On the Town +

Christopher Gattelli – Rodgers and Hammerstein’s The King and I

Scott Graham and Steven Hoggett for Frantic Assembly – The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time

Casey Nicholaw – Something Rotten!

Christopher Wheeldon – An American in Paris*

I honestly feel that if Christopher Wheeldon does not win the directing category, he needs to receive a Tony for his choreography in An American in Paris. He not only makes ballet look sexy and elegant, but he really tells a beautiful story through his choreography while also tipping his hat to the beautiful choreography from the source material. However, do not count out Joshua Bergasse’s choreography in On the Town. It is so brilliant, flashy and screams musical theatre it is not even funny. It is one of the many things that compliments that great production.

BEST DIRECTOR OF A PLAY

Stephen Daldry – Skylight

Marianne Elliott – The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time*

Scott Ellis – You Can’t Take It With You +

Jeremy Herrin – Wolf Hall: Parts One & Two

Moritz von Stuelpnagel – Hand to God

Marianne Elliott’s direction of this play is amazing. Not only is the staging smart and eye candy for the audience, but it is also has scenes that beautifully done by Elliott. However, I would not be upset if Scott Ellis won for You Can’t Take It With You. He is an incredible director whose work is amazing, and from what I heard, he directed this star studded ensemble cast beautifully. I feel that is amazing someone to be able to do that to tell you the truth due to the many components.

BEST DIRECTOR OF A MUSICAL

Sam Gold – Fun Home*

Casey Nicholaw – Something Rotten!

John Rando – On the Town

Bartlett Sher – Rodgers and Hammerstein’s The King and I +

Christopher Wheeldon – An American in Paris

To say that Sam Gold had his work cut out for him would be an understatement. Not only did he have the daunting task of directing a musical that was based on an unlikely source for a musical, but he staged and directed many moments beautifully in this show. To say that he was the fearless captain on this ship would be an understatement. He is completely deserving of this award. However, let’s not count out Bartlett Sher. This is his second time directing a Rodgers and Hammerstein revival, and I think it is just as great as his Tony award winning production of South Pacific. He literally found a way to make the show vibrant, feel relevant to 2015 and find the beauty/romance in the piece. I would not be upset if he won again because his direction of this production is ravishing.

MUSIC AND WRITING CATEGORIES

BEST ORCHESTRATIONS

An American in Paris

Fun Home*

The Last Ship+

Something Rotten!

I honestly feel that it is a toss up between the two big contenders for Best Musical in this category. On the one thing this would be the only music category An American in Paris would win because it is not eligible for Best Original Score, and it would be deserving because the orchestrations in this production are elegant and pleasant to the ear. They really take these Gershwin songs and make them sound fresh and timeless. However, I feel Fun Home‘s orchestrations are just as deserving and should win because of the small orchestra being so powerful in this beautiful piece. However, do not count out The Last Ship. Although I liked the score and feel it will not win Best Original Score, I did love the orchestrations in this show, and felt they were brilliantly used in this piece. Just give a listen with the clips above and see what you think.

BEST BOOK OF A MUSICAL

Craig Lucas – An American in Paris

Lisa Kron – Fun Home*+

Karey Kirkpatrick and John O’Farrell – Something Rotten!

Terrence McNally – The Visit

If Lisa Kron does not get award for Best Book of a Musical this season…I may boycott the Tonys. LISTEN….the book for Fun Home is literally the best, seriously well crafted book on Broadway this season. I started reading Alison Bechdel’s graphic novel that the musical is based on one day in a Barnes & Noble, and it still amazes me how she was able to adapt this book, which seemed impossible, and make it work for the stage. Don’t get me wrong, I love Craig Lucas and feel he is a wonderful book writer, especially with The Light in the Piazza, and of course who does not love a Terrence McNally book, but I feel this is the year of female writers to come out on top, especially Lisa Kron.

BEST ORIGINAL SCORE

Fun Home – Music: Jeanine Tesori; Lyrics: Lisa Kron*+

The Last Ship – Music and Lyrics: Sting

Something Rotten! – Music and Lyrics: Wayne Kirkpatrick and Karey Kikrpatrick

The Visit – Music: John Kander; Lyrics: Fred Ebb

I’m going to say it…and I feel like I’m going out on a limb here…Fun Home has literally the best score on Broadway this season, maybe the best in the past 4-5 years. Don’t get me wrong, there are some scores that are brilliant and wonderful, but this one is literally the list of a handful of musicals that had a score that made emotionally compromised. The last musical to do that was Ragtime: The Musical, which is my favorite musicals of all time. I think for once a brand new show might be on my top ten after this season. Just listen to these three songs from the show. They are powerful, moving and just amazing. Also, the other aspect of this award that makes me hopeful is that Jeanine Tesori, who wrote shows such as Violet, Shrek, and Caroline, or Change, will FINALLY win a Tony award because she is one of those composers who is incredible.

ACTING CATEGORIES

BEST FEATURED ACTRESS IN A PLAY

Annaleigh Ashford – You Can’t Take It With You; Role – Essie*

Patricia Clarkson – The Elephant Man; Role – Mrs. Kendal/Pinhead+

Lydia Leonard – Wolf Hall: Parts One & Two; Role – Anne Boleyn+

Sarah Stiles – Hand to God; Role – Jessica

Julie White – Airline Highway; Role – Tanya

I’m going to say this now while we are on the acting categories, but this year each category is packed with some amazing nominees that are equally as deserving. However, I have to say Annaleigh Ashford is going to win and should win this award. I’ve seen clips of her in this show, and she literally is the epitome of scene stealer. She also carries her own in a very star studded revival, and has been working for a while in some great roles where she shines. I feel it would be a great way to say here’s a thank you for all these great roles you have given us, including Essie. However, do not count out Patricia Clarkson, who from what I have seen, gave a beautiful performance in The Elephant Man. And also do not count out Lydia Leonard in Wolf Hall, who I have read nothing but glowing reviews of her hautning portrayal of Anne Boleyn.

BEST FEATURED ACTOR IN A PLAY

Matthew Beard – Skylight; Role – Edward Sergeant

K. Todd Freeman – Airline Highway; Role – Sissy Na Na

Richard McCabe – The Audience; Role – Harold Wilson

Alessandro Nivola – The Elephant Man; Role – Frederick Treves *+

Nathaniel Parker – Wolf Hall: Parts One & Two; Role – King Henry VIII*

Micah Stock – It’s Only a Play; Role – Gus P. Head

I feel it would kinda awesome for Nathaniel Parker to win for his portrayal of King Henry VIII because he has already won an Olivier Award. However, I feel Alessandro Nivola, who also random fact was in Jurassic Park III, is just as deserving for his role in The Elephant Man. Both are equally deserving of the award for their roles this season, but again I think it would be really cool for Parker to win. Plus, who doesn’t love someone playing one of the most scandalous men in power since President Fitzgerald Grant (EEEYYYOOOO!!!!)

BEST FEATURED ACTRESS IN A MUSICAL

Victoria Clark – Gigi; Role – Mamita

Judy Kuhn – Fun Home; Role – Helen*

Sydney Lucas – Fun Home; Role – Small Alison*

Ruthie Ann Miles – Rodgers and Hammerstein’s The King and I; Role – Lady Thiang+

Emily Skeggs – Fun Home; Role – Medium Alison

This category is one of two where I literally do not know who will win this category. I think it’s mainly because there are three women nominated for the same show, and there are three women that are equally deserving for this award. Personally, I want Sydney Lucas to win because she is literally giving the best performance ever performed by a child actress. I feel she is going to be the next Daisy Egan and be the first child actress since 1991 to win a Tony Award. However, I somehow feel that Judy Kuhn might win the award, which would make me excited to be honest. I think it might be because she is the voice of my childhood (BUT REALLY THOUGH…she was the singing voice for Pocahontas y’all) and I’m so excited she has a role that feels like it is written for her. And her voice in this show is angelic. But, again, I would be so happy if either of those actresses received this award because they are giving career defining performances. However, incase the Fun Home actresses cancel each other out, I would not mind seeing Ruthie Ann Miles win for The King and I. Not only does she sing “Something Wonderful” beautifully, but she gives so much more depth to the character that it is refreshing to see the role in a new light. Again, would not be mad to have one of these three women win the award.

BEST FEATURED ACTOR IN A MUSICAL

Christian Borle – Something Rotten!; Role – Shakespeare

Andy Karl – On the Twentieth Century; Role – Bruce Granit*+

Brad Oscar – Something Rotten!; Role – Nostradamus

Brandon Uranowitz – An American in Paris; Role – Adam Hochberg

Max von Essen – An American in Paris; Role – Henri Baurel

So, I think it is clear that Christian Borle, and his arms (THEY’RE SO NICE!!!) will be the big winner for this category. Plus, I think he should deserve every award that he receives for this role because he is giving a stellar performance. However, I would not be upset is Andy Karl won for On the Twentieth Century because he literally is showing his range within the past two years. He was nominated for Rocky last year, and now goes from drama to comedy, and is giving another great performance (with his arms). Again, I think it will be Christian Borle, but I would not be upset if it was Andy Karl.

BEST LEADING ACTRESS IN A PLAY

Geneva Carr – Hand to God; Role – Margery

Helen Mirren – The Audience; Role – Queen Elizabeth II*

Elisabeth Moss – The Heidi Chronicles; Role – Heidi Holland

Carey Mulligan – Skylight; Role – Kyra Hollis+

Ruth Wilson – Constellations; Role – Marianne

I think this is going to be a big first this year in this category. If Helen Mirren wins the Tony tomorrow night for her performance in The Audience, she will be the first actress to play a role that has earned her an Academy Award and a Tony Award. She looks exquisite in the show, and really gives such a stunning performance as Queen Elizabeth II. However, do not count out Carey Mulligan because, from what I’ve been reading, she is acting the poop out of her role. But, I still think it’s going to be Helen Mirren’s night.

BEST LEADING ACTOR IN A PLAY

Steven Boyer – Hand to God; Role – Jason/Tyrone

Bradley Cooper – The Elephant Man; Role – John Merrick*

Ben Miles – Wolf Hall: Parts One & Two; Role – Thomas Cromwell

Bill Nighy – Skylight; Role – Tom Sergeant+

Alex Sharp – The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time; Role – Christopher

This is another packed category this year, and I feel it could co in a lot of ways. I feel the recipient of this award will be Alex Sharp for Curious Incident, and he does deserve it because he is giving a riveting physical performance in the role of Christopher. Plus it boggles my mind that he is a recent graduate from Julliard, gets his Broadway debut, and then now has a Tony nom. To say it is a Cinderella story is an understatement. However, the award could also go to Bradley Cooper, who gave the most talked about performance in The Elephant Man, and as it should go to him because he loves the project, believes in it, brought it to London, and was a class act as a big A-list star coming to Hollywood. It’s because of this I respect him as an actor. Finally, let’s not count out Bill Nighy who is giving another great performance in Skylight, which I feel might make him the big surprise of the evening.

BEST LEADING ACTRESS IN A MUSICAL

Kristin Chenoweth – On the Twentieth Century; Role – Lily Garland/Mildred Plotka+

Leanne Cope – An American in Paris; Role – Lise Dassin

Beth Malone – Fun Home; Role – Alison

Kelli O’Hara – Rodgers and Hammerstein’s The King and I; Role – Anna Leonowens*

Chita Rivera – The Visit; Role – Claire Zacahanassian

Okay all, I’m gonna level with y’all. All five of these women are giving the performance of their careers. Each women are deserving and creating beautiful work on stage. You have Beth Malone as Alison in Fun Home that gives a heart wrenching performance, Leanne Cope giving a beautiful Broadway debut, and Chita Rivera in her last stage role. However, I feel the award is going between Kristin Chenoweth and Kelli O’Hara. Personally, I feel Kelli O’Hara should win the award. She is giving another incredible performance in a Rodgers and Hammerstein show, that really is her bread and butter, and it feels like the role that will finally give her an award that she finally deserves at this point in her career. Plus she has a voice like an angel, and sings the score so beautifully. She is my khaleesi. However, Kristin Chenoweth is giving another amazing performance, and I feel that she could also win the award. She is carrying the show on her shoulders, and literally singing the poop out of the role of Lily Garland. If either one of these women received the award, I would not be upset. Again, I want it to be Kelli O’Hara, however, it would be pleasant if Kristin Chenoweth also won.

BEST LEADING ACTOR IN A MUSICAL

Michael Ceveris – Fun Home; Role – Bruce*

Robert Fairchild – An American in Paris; Role – Jerry Mulligan

Brian d’Arcy James – Something Rotten!; Role – Nick Bottom +

Ken Watanabe – Rodgers and Hammerstein’s The King and I; Role – The King of Siam

Tony Yazbeck – On the Town; Role – Gabey

I feel the award is between three actors: Michael Ceveris, Robert Fairchild, and Brian d’Arcy James. Personally, I would love to see Michael Ceveris win for his portrayal of Bruce in the show, and he should win. He is the glue that holds the show together by being the father Alison talks about throughout the evening. Plus, he gives a heart breaking performance as a really tortured man. However, I would not count out Brian d’Arcy James. I love him as an actor/vocalist, and feel he could win the award in a musical that he is giving a high energy performance. But, again, I firmly believe that Michael Ceveris will win, and he deserves it for this incredible show.

PRODUCTION CATEGORIES

BEST REVIVAL OF A PLAY

The Elephant Man*+

Skylight

This Is Our Youth

You Can’t Take It With You*

I feel like it’s a toss up again in this category. I feel it is between two shows that opened in the fall, and made a huge impact on the season. I really would love to see You Can’t Take It With You receive this award because it has been a while since the show was revived, and it was a production that was incredibly hysterical. However, do not count out The Elephant Man. It played to sold out audiences all throughout the winter and early spring, and was quite a wonderful production with an even more wonderful cast.

BEST REVIVAL OF A MUSICAL

Rodgers and Hammerstein’s The King and I*

On the Town

On the Twentieth Century +

As everyone who knows me knows, I am obsessed with this production of The King and I. It is one of the Rodgers and Hammerstein shows that I have never seen on stage, it stars one of my favorite actresses, and it opened on my birthday. Plus the production is flawless, ravishing and fabulous. It also does this beautiful job of bringing such a classic to the modern world, and fleshing out the drama and romance in the piece. I feel it is a slam dunk for this production. However, do not count out On the Twentieth Century. It has become a huge hit in its limited engagement, and really is a great revival of such a fun musical comedy.

BEST PLAY

The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time*

Disgraced

Hand to God

Wolf Hall: Parts One & Two +

Another slam dunk for Curious Incident. It is literally the best play that has opened this season. All my friends who have seen it have told me it is incredible, an event at the theatre, and very moving. Also, I feel it will be amazing to see a show that opened in the fall and has literally been the hot ticket all season to win the Tony award. It is a brilliant adaptation of the novel, and does a beautiful job of showing individuals with Asperger’s or autism on stage. However, from what I’ve heard, Wolf Hall is another faithful adaptation to the novel, and is quite thrilling to watch on stage. But, again, I think it will be Curious Incident taking the award home.

BEST MUSICAL

An American in Paris

Fun Home*+

Something Rotten!

The Visit

Although this has been a great year with musicals. This year nominated for Best Musical we have only one musical this year based on a film, one completely original musical, one based on a graphic novel, and another based on a play. Ultimately, I strongly believe that Fun Home will take the prize. It is nothing like what is on Broadway right now. It is a beautiful piece about finding yourself, how to cope with loss, and empowerment of yourself. The score is spectacular, the acting is superb and the production value is simple, but amazing. I know some are think An American in Paris will win based on the fact it is something that everyone relates to, and is able to tour around the country as a selling point.

(WARNING: Soapbox Moment) I’m sorry, but y’all need to understand something. The Tony voters have picked art over what sells on tour better over the years. Last year’s A Gentleman’s Guide to Love and Murder was more of an art form than a sell for touring, which if we were going off of that Beautiful: The Carole King Musical or Aladdin. Billy Elliot: The Musical was a piece of art. Once was a work of art. The Book of Mormon, in some circles, is a hard sell with the creators of South Park being the creators. Int he past 5 years, I’ve only seen 2 musicals win for Best Musical that would be considered a great touring show to sell to touring companies. Also, what is not relatable about finding yourself. Even though Fun Home is about a lesbian coming into her own, anyone can relate to it. Gays, straights, bis, thais, dinosaurs, frogs…anyone can relate to it. I honestly feel the Tony voters will choose a show that is very moving, well crafted, and truly a work of art over what sells better on the road.

So, again, I’m Fun Home all the way.

Well, those are my predictions for the Tony awards. If you all feel like watching a great night of seeing theatre being honored on television, tune in on CBS tomorrow night at 8 pm/7pm central.

Do you have any predictions or thoughts? Please feel free to leave comments below!! I am so glad that I’m back to blogging for all of you, and I cannot wait to do some pieces for you all. First, I have to release my reviews of Avengers: Age of Ultron and Pitch Perfect 2, which were amazing. Also you can look forward to a movie musical based post for Tony month, with reviews of Jurassic World and Inside Out.

Until next time folks,

Your Favorite Ginger

Hey all,

So today, March 22, is a special someone’s birthday. Today is the 85th birthday of the great musical theatre composer Stephen Sondheim. (I KNOW….IT’S HARD TO BELIEVE HE’S 85…HE BETTA!!)

Stephen Sondheim’s work holds a special place in my heart because he was one of the most influential composers in my adolescent years. I remember seeing Into the Woods for the first time in middle school (actually I remember getting it through Netflix on my last day of 6th grade) and being enthralled with his music. It was like nothing I heard before, and his lyrics were incredible. Since then, I have been very obsessed with his work. So to commemorate today, I thought I would make a Ginger’s Top Picks with my personal top 10 Stephen Sondheim musicals. I might cause some high brow musical theatre debates, which is okay and makes you folks talk, but, hey it’s my personal opinion. Here are the Ginger’s Top 10 Sondheim Musicals. (Included with each show is some show credits/info provided by PlaybillVault.com, which y’all MTN’s need to look into because this sight is the bomb diggity, and Wikipedia.)

10. Merrily We Roll Along

This little cult of a musical makes the first appearance on this countdown. The musical, based on the George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart play but updated, tells the journey of three friends and how fame tests them, and ultimately tears them apart. Simple right? Not with this musical. You see, this musical takes that plot concept and takes the audience on a backwards journey. So we start the show in 1976 and end the show in 1957. CRAZY!! What’s even crazier is this was considered as Sondheim’s biggest flop in his career and ended his partnership with Hal Prince until 2003. I did not really become familiar with this show personally until I the summer I started my masters. I knew about some song gems that are just genius and gorgeous, especially “Not a Day Goes By”, “Old Friends” and “Franklin Shepard, Inc.”. But, although I see how it initially did not do well because of the concept, this is honestly a great show. The characters are literally fleshed out and real, especially the trio of friends (Frank, Charley and Mary), and there are moments that beautiful on stage. It also is a show that screams Sondheim. Just take a listen at some songs from this show, it’s beautiful.

Some Show Credits/InfoBook: George Furth

Theatre of Broadway Premiere: Alvin Theater (now the Neil Simon Theatre)

Opening Night: November 16, 1981

Closing Night: November 28, 1981

Performances: 16

Cast: Jim Walton (Frank), Lonny Price (Charley), Ann Morrison (Mary), Sally Kelin (Beth), Jason Alexander (Joe), Terry Finn (Gussie)

Revivals: 1994 Off-Broadway Revival Production (this is the current licensing version through MTI)

Another NY Production: 2012 Encores Concert (starring Colin Donnell, Celia Keenan-Bolger, Lin-Manuel Miranda, Betsy Wolfe and Elizabeth Stanley)

Notable Songs: “Merrily We Roll Along”, “Old Friends”, “Growing Up”, “Not a Day Goes By”, “Good Thing Going”, “Opening Doors”, “Our Time”

9. Follies

To explain this musical in a nutshell, it’s about a group of retired dancers/singers from the “Weismann’s Follies” (based on the Ziegfeld Follies) have a reunion in their crumbling theatre, which is scheduled for demolition. The main focus is about two couples, Buddy and Sally Durant Plummer, and Benjamin and Phyllis Rogers Stone, who’s past comes back to haunt them. This show was a big success, following very closely after Sondheim’s first mega hit Company. There are some great songs that are just simple and smart. The plot, in my opinion, is very depressing because these people are clearly in the wrong relationship, and end up staying in their unhappy relationship by the end of the show. This also features some great supporting characters that get some star shining moments, especially Carlotta Campion and Hattie Walker. Also, some great show stopping solos from the leads.

Some Show Credits/Info

Book: James Goldman

Theatre of Broadway Premiere: Winter Garden Theatre

Opening Night: April 4, 1971

Closing Night: July 1, 1972

Performances: 522

Cast: Alexis Smith (Phyllis), John McMartin (Ben), Dorothy Collins (Sally), Gene Nelson (Buddy), Yvonne De Carlo (Carlotta)

Tony Awards: Best Director of a Musical, Best Leading Actress in a Musical (Alexis Smith), Best Original Score, Best Choreography, Best Scenic Design, Best Costume Design, Best Lighting Design

Revivals: 2001 Broadway Revival Production (starring Blythe Danner and Judith Ivey)

2011 Broadway Revival Production (starring Bernadette Peters, Jan Maxwell, Elaine Page, Rob Raines and Danny Burstein; Winner of a Tony Award for Best Costume Design)

Notable Songs: “Beautiful Girls”, “In Buddy’s Eyes”, “I’m Still Here”, “Too Many Mornings”, “Could I Leave You?”, “You’re Gonna Love Tomorrow/Love Will See Us Through”, “The God-Why-Don’t-You-Love-Me Blues”, “Losing My Mind”, “The Story of Lucy and Jessie”

8. West Side Story

This is the only show on the countdown where Sondheim wrote the lyrics, and not the music. Basically a modernization of Romeo and Juliet, this show has a moving score, and even more great lyrics. The lyrics in this musical are smart while also filling in the times of being charming. What is surprising is this musical was not popular until the hit that was the 1961 film version. Although it is not the same as the show, it is a pretty incredible film. This was also Sondheim’s first Broadway show produced on Broadway. Here are some songs from this classic.

Some Show Credits/Info

Music: Leonard Bernstein

Book: Arthur Laurents

Theatre of Broadway Premiere: Winter Garden Theatre

Opening Night: September 26, 1957

Closing Night: June 27, 1959

Performances: 732

Cast: Larry Kert (Tony), Carol Lawrence (Maria), Chita Rivera (Anita), Ken Leroy (Benrardo), Mikey Calin (Riff)

Tony Awards: Best Choreography and Best Sound Design

Revivals: 1980 Broadway Revival Production (starring Debbie Allen and Josie de Guzman)

2009 Broadway Revival Production (starring Matt Cavenaugh, Josefina Scaglione, Karen Olivo; Winner of a Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Musical (Karen Olivo))

Film Version: 1961 starring Richard Beymer, Natalie Wood, Russ Tamblyn, Rita Moreno, Geoge Chakiris

Notable Songs: “Something’s Coming”, “America”, “Cool”, “Tonight”, “I Feel Pretty”, “Gee, Officer Krupke”, “A Boy Like That/I Have A Love”

7. Passion

If there ever was a a score from Sondheim that is romantic and gorgeous, next to A Little Night Music, this is the show. Based on the Ettore Scola film Passione d’Amore, this beautiful show tells the story of a soldier, Giorgio, who is away from his love, Clara, and becomes the object of his captain’s cousin’s, Fosca, obsession. Eventually Giorgio learns to love Fosca as the woman who loves him unconditionally, no matter what. What is also interesting about this show is a pseudo-opera. It is beautiful, lush, and difficult for any singer, and keeps the action moving through music. There is just a lot of things to love about this show.

6. Company

This show is a great representation of relationships, and many peoples views on marriage. It was so ground breaking for its time that it sparked the idea of the modern musical theatre piece. There are so many great things about this show. The characters are real and three dimensional, the writing is fantastic, and the idea of Bobby being the blank slate and being molded into the man they want him to be, which he fights against and finds a voice for himself. The moment he says, “But who will I have to take care of?” is the most amazing part of the show. The songs are also beautiful, catchy, and character driven. It’s just a great musical that really started the big successful waves of mega hits in the 1970s.

5. Assassins

What do you get when you mix Sondheim with some of the most hated assassins in United States history? Musical theatre gold!! I was not familiar with this show until my college did it during my junior year. This show is amazing in its concept, music and character development. There is so much I can say about this show and how brilliant it is, but then it would be a long section. Just listen to some of the music on the clips, and see for yourself. And the craziest part of it all is it did not make its Broadway premiere until 2004. It had been a huge success in 1990 Off-Broadway and other regional productions.

4. Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street

I think I might have caused the high brow musical theatre debates by putting this at number 4 instead of number one, but hey at least it is on my top 5. This easily one of Sondheim’s masterpieces. The score is filled with amazing orchestrations, some incredible songs and harmonies, and scary at some moments. If there was any time Sondheim wrote an opera, this is where you can argue that. It’s similar to Milton Babbit or Berg’s Wozzeck. Plus there is nothing like hearing Angela Lansbury and Len Cariou sing this score. It just gives you goosebumps. Seeing this growing up made me realize how much of a genius Sondheim really is in the musical theatre world. Also, this is one of his most performed musical, next to Into the Woods.

3. Into the Woods

Just like Assassins, Into the Woods is the result of when you mix Sondheim with Grimm Fairy Tales. There is no surprise that this show ended up so high on my list because it was the first Sondheim musical i have ever seen. At first, growing up, I did not like the plot of it because of the young age I was. I had a love hate relationship with this musical. But, when my college did it my senior year, and I saw the show again after all the things I have been through in life, I loved it and felt it was a great piece of musical theatre. I understand why colleges and high schools do this musical, and why the piece has a longevity. Not only does have this great, challenging score, it contains this plot that is central, beautiful and talks about everything we face with parenting, adolescence, and growing up. Plus, I love the fact it beat a little show known as The Phantom of the Opera for Best Original Score and Best Book of a Musical.

2. A Little Night Music

This show really has a special place in my heart. It was my senior high school show, and one of the best experiences of my life. I find this show one of the best shows produced by Sondheim. It used to be my number one, until I finally was introduced to our number one pick on this countdown. Based on the Igmar Bergman film, it has a Midsummer Night’s Dream quality to the plot where couples are with the wrong person, but somehow by the end of the show, they end up with the right person. It is also very sensual for a musical, and there are some scenes that are just brilliantly written for any actor. And the music is simplistic, like drinking champagne, and has some brilliant lyrics. Also, I really hope there is a new, better film version than the one from 1977 with Elizabeth Taylor. It’s pretty bad. But, the show is amazing and that’s all you need to know.

1. Sunday in the Park with George

This music has one of those scores that without fail will give me chills and make me burst out in tears. It is literally up there with Ragtime. This musical is literally two one act shows in one, like Into the Woods. You have the first act with a fictional look into the life of pointillism artist George Seurat. The second act is a look into the future with his great-grandchild, and how he is facing the same creative challenge as the George in the first act. I find this show to be beautiful with it’s score, scope and look. It is quite a moving show, especially being an aspiring artist. Sometimes I just pop it in when I am feeling inspired, or want a good cry sometimes. The harmonies in “Sunday”….I cry thinking about it. Just listen to some songs, and just witness this exquisite score.
